message:
حد عنده فكرة عن مستقبل ال PHP بعد لما asp.net تشتغل على لينكس وماك
يعني الواحد يرتب نفسه على asp.net  من دلوقتي ولا ايه؟ 
انا شغال PHP ومش عارف المستقبل هيكون افضل مع مين من حيث security & extensiblty & ease of code
وايه الحلو اللي هيبقى موجود في PHP بعد كده؟
شكرا

data.message: ana a3taqad en mafesh wa7ed menhom haytaraga3 .. 7agm el a3mal elly mawgood fe el etneen we 7agm el nas elly beyshtaghal fehom yekhaly men el mosta7el wa7ed menhom yentehy.. ana shayf en el mosta2abal haykoon lelly enta shater feh aktar we elly te2dar temayz nafsak feeh
Try to learn Ruby on Rails :)
ايه اللي بيفضلها عن php and asp.net

.NET is not a threat to PHP. E market is big enough to handle both.

With backing from Facebook, WordPress and others, PHP is here to stay.

Read more about it.
How many products and companies use rails now. Its the future

Like Meligy said, there's room for everyone. But I'm here to comment on the call to learn Ruby on Rails. I've been doing ruby for so long that I've seen this comment creep up almost everywhere, along side to nodejs, python and lisp. Now lisp, is easy to justify.

But please, could we just stop with the "learn something" because fuck it's cool or popular? Could we be a bit more objective, justify your suggestion.

Don't just throw a "learn x" without giving a person some reasons why they should take your word for it.
It is not a zero-sum game, both ASP.net and PHP are mature technologies and attracts different types of developers every day.

Rails is not the future. Rails, and .NET, are each one part of the present. it's not the shiny new toy anymore (that's node now) but many people make living from it, like others who earn from .NET, and PHP. Cool to learn another tool and add it to your bag of tricks, but you don't "have to" most likely
اعتقد لا غنى عن ال بي إتش بي لكن ف نفس الوقت خطوة كبيرة من .Net تحسب بشكل كبير
Move out to rails dude =D

@hady Ahmed
He should take it or leave it and the same for you :)

Like I said, be objective and state your reasons if you know any and are not just reiterating a hyperbole suggestion because it sounds cool and looks cooler. That's how we establish rich arguments and enrich one another with our backgrounds and experiences.

Blanket statements tell me one of two things, either the person knows too little about what they're talking about or they're just throwing in their 2 cents for the sake of participating but adding nothing.
Abou Youssef Saad

بص الموضوع آن آنت في سوق و مهارتك هى السلعة لو مهاراتك مشايهة لمهارات الي معاك في السوق حيبقى الطلب عليك قليل، خةها من المنطق ةا حتلاقي ال PHP and .NET مهارات ماليه السوق، آنت حاول تشوف السوق فيه إيه مميز و آتعلمه و حتلاقي الطلب عليك كتير و كمان المهارة سعرها أغلى.
أنا عن نفسي رحت ل Python and Django لو لاحظت آن السوق كبير و الطلب كتير و الموارد قليلة
ruby :D
ASP.NET open source might go really far or might just get worst! why do I need a heavy language to be running in a small instance. I'd go for something lighter that can scale nicely ;)
لما يموت ال wordpress  هيبان حجم ال php

Alaa, there is s new framework called .NET core. It's like RVM (Ruby Version Manager) and is very light that every application can have it's own version of the framework.

Everything is now in packages. ASP.NET 5 (in the works) is a complete rewrite of ASP.NET and a decoupling of the entire. NET into NuGet (think NPM) packages.

Badawi, WordPresd is not dying any time soon. Definitely not just because there are other lighter alternatives out there.

There is a whole ecosystem around WordPress, businesses worth lots of millions of dollars built just around WordPress.

For marketers and other business people who just need a flexible CMS the WordPress ecosystem with all plugins and commercial offerings available is yet to have any proper competition, those are the ones that pay money, and their money keeps the ecosystem alive

As I said, the market is big enough to handle competitive platforms simultaneously. Just stop thinking that the success of one platform necessarily means the death of another. That's just silly. I mean really, just stop.
